elements.content: Synthesis of new porous materials has been developed for efficient capture of pollutants in environmental sciences. Here, the application of a new metal–organic framework (TMU-30) has been reported based on isonicotinate N-oxide as an adsorptive site for fast and highly efficient aqueous phase adsorption of Cr­(VI). The adsorption process showed no remarkable effect over a pH range of 2–9. The maximum capacity of the adsorption was reached in just less than 10 min and followed the pseudo-second-order kinetics. The maximum capacity of 2.86 mol mol–1 (145 mg/g) was obtained according to Langmuir model at 298 K. The spontaneous adsorption and an endothermic process were controlled by positive entropy changes. XPS analysis revealed electrostatic interactions between N-oxide groups of TMU-30 and Cr­(VI) species, which were responsible for the adsorption process.

XPS analysis revealed electrostatic interactions between N-oxide groups of TMU-30 and Cr(VI) species, which were responsible for the adsorption process.

elements.content: A new metal−organic framework (MOF) containing N-oxide groups has been used for highly efficient adsorption of Cr­(VI) from aqueous solutions with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol−1 or 145 mg g−1).
elements.clean_text: A new metal-organic framework (MOF) containing N-oxide groups has been used for highly efficient adsorption of Cr(VI) from aqueous solutions with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol-1 or 145 mg g-1).

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed greatly in recent years. Porous frameworks of MOFs can be tuned for their characteristics such as pore sizes, surface areas, organic functional groups, thermal stability, and available metal sites. These types of structures have attracted intensive interest in gas adsorption, storage, sensing, drug delivery, catalysis, and photocatalysis, but they are less investigated for pollutant adsorption and removal. MOFs are suitable candidates for liquid phase adsorption due to their pore size distributions. Stability of MOFs in water has become a challenging issue in aqueous phase separations. MOF behavior in the presence of water is a topic of significant importance when considering these materials for adsorption applications.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been developed greatly in recent years. Porous frameworks of MOFs can be tuned for their characteristics such as pore sizes, surface areas, organic functional groups, thermal stability, and available metal sites. These types of structures have attracted intensive interest in gas adsorption, storage, sensing, drug delivery, catalysis, and photocatalysis, but they are less investigated for pollutant adsorption and removal. MOFs are suitable candidates for liquid phase adsorption due to their pore size distributions. Stability of MOFs in water has become a challenging issue in aqueous phase separations. MOF behavior in the presence of water is a topic of significant importance when considering these materials for adsorption applications.

elements.content: Cr­(VI), which is produced by some sources related to the genesis and development of the human, is identified as a common pollutant because of its high toxicity and mobility. The Environmental Protection Agency’s (EPA) legal limit for total chromium is 100 ppb in drinking water. Investigation of new materials for efficient adsorption and removal of Cr­(VI) is extremely important because conventional operation technologies and materials possess insufficient capacities, slow rates, and low selectivity. The presence of particular functional groups on the surface may enhance the adsorption selectivity and efficiency of MOFs toward certain contaminants. The isonicotinic acid N-oxide ligand contains two different coordinating groups in which the carboxylate groups act in different modes and N-oxide groups possess opposite charges on nitrogen and oxygen atoms. Such intrinsic features increase the flexibility and enrich coordination modes to form fascinating structures. Newly synthesized cationic MOFs have been applied for exchange and removal of oxo-anion contaminants, such as ReO4 –, CrO4 2, and TcO4 –, but to the best of our knowledge, there has been no report of MOFs with inherent potential positive charge. The main aim of this research is to prepare a MOF with sufficient water stability that can be used as an adsorbent for highly efficient Cr­(VI) adsorption from aqueous solutions.

elements.content: Here, we designed and synthesized a new 3D framework, [Pb­(INO)2]2·DMF (TMU-30), (TMU stands for Tarbiat Modares University), based on isonicotinate N-oxide (INO) consisting of 1D channels. N-Oxide groups with a potential positive charge can be an appropriate site for efficient adsorption of chromate species and generate electrostatic interactions with them. The effects of various experimental parameters like pH, initial Cr­(VI) concentration, contact time, and temperature are examined on Cr­(VI) adsorption. Fast adsorption kinetics, large adsorption capacity, and excellent water stability over a wide range of pH (2–9) make TMU-30 a high potential adsorbent to adsorb Cr­(VI) from water.
elements.clean_text: Here, we designed and synthesized a new 3D framework, [Pb(INO)2]2⋅DMF (TMU-30), (TMU stands for Tarbiat Modares University), based on isonicotinate N-oxide (INO) consisting of 1D channels. N-Oxide groups with a potential positive charge can be an appropriate site for efficient adsorption of chromate species and generate electrostatic interactions with them. The effects of various experimental parameters like pH, initial Cr(VI) concentration, contact time, and temperature are examined on Cr(VI) adsorption. Fast adsorption kinetics, large adsorption capacity, and excellent water stability over a wide range of pH (2-9) make TMU-30 a high potential adsorbent to adsorb Cr(VI) from water.

elements.content: Lead­(II) nitrate, potassium chromate, and isonicotinic acid N-oxide (HINO) were purchased from Merck and Aldrich. An Electrothermal 9100 apparatus was applied for melting point measurements. IR spectra were measured on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet IR100 (Madison, WI) Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer. The thermal behavior was investigated by a PL-STA 1500 apparatus at a temperature ramp of 10 °C min–1 up to 600 °C under a continuous flow of dry nitrogen. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured with a Philips X’pert diffractometer by using monochromated Co Kα radiation (generator tension and current, 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively). After adsorption, TMU-30 was characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) on a Hitachi S4160 instrument with a gold coating. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was used for simultaneous determination of the target elements on a Varian Vista-PRO instrument (Springvale, Australia) with a charge-coupled detector (CCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the samples was conducted with a Bestec instrument (Germany).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instrumentations

Lead(II) nitrate, potassium chromate, and isonicotinic acid N-oxide (HINO) were purchased from Merck and Aldrich. An Electrothermal 9100 apparatus was applied for melting point measurements. IR spectra were measured on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet IR100 (Madison, WI) Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrometer. The thermal behavior was investigated by a PL-STA 1500 apparatus at a temperature ramp of 10 °C min-1 up to 600 °C under a continuous flow of dry nitrogen. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured with a Philips X'pert diffractometer by using monochromated Co Kα radiation (generator tension and current, 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively). After adsorption, TMU-30 was characterized by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) on a Hitachi S4160 instrument with a gold coating. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) was used for simultaneous determination of the target elements on a Varian Vista-PRO instrument (Springvale, Australia) with a charge-coupled detector (CCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the samples was conducted with a Bestec instrument (Germany).

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray data were collected on a STOE IPDS II image plate diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K by using the ω-scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined through the full-matrix least-squares method using SHELXL-97: Data collection, Stoe X-AREA; cell refinement, Stoe X-AREA; data reduction, Stoe XRED. Analysis of the structure and presentation of the results were carried out by PLATON and ORTEP-3 software.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Analysis

The single-crystal X-ray data were collected on a STOE IPDS II image plate diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K by using the ω-scan technique. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined through the full-matrix least-squares method using SHELXL-97: Data collection, Stoe X-AREA; cell refinement, Stoe X-AREA; data reduction, Stoe XRED. Analysis of the structure and presentation of the results were carried out by PLATON and ORTEP-3 software.

elements.content: TMU-30 single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were synthesized by vial method (Figure S1 in the SI). Pb­(NO3)2 (0.01 g, 0.3 mmol) and HINO (0.084 g, 0.6 mmol) were mixed in 20 mL of DMF. The mixture was stirred until complete dissolution, and then it was dispensed into several vials, and the vials were kept in an oven with the temperature of 353 K. After 72 h, yellow crystals of TMU-30 (Figure S1 in the SI) were separated from mother solution (yield 80% based on Pb, bp >573 K). FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 635 cm–1 (s, v (Pb–O)), 783 cm–1 (m, v oop (C–H)ring), 860 cm–1 (s, v (C–C)), 1134 cm–1 (s, v (C–H)ring), 1210 cm–1 (vs, v (N–O) N‑oxide), 1376 cm–1 (vs, v sym (CO2–Pb)), 1480 (m, v (CC)ring), 1543 and 1585 cm–1 (s, v asym (CO2–Pb)), 1655 cm–1 (m, v (CO)DMF), 3101 cm–1 (w, v sym (C–H)). Elemental analysis (%) calculated: C 30.38, H 1.95, N 6.83. Found: C 30.4, H 2.1, N 7.2.

The mixture was stirred until complete dissolution, and then it was dispensed into several vials, and the vials were kept in an oven with the temperature of 353 K. After 72 h, yellow crystals of TMU-30 (Figure S1 in the SI) were separated from mother solution (yield 80% based on Pb, bp >573 K). FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 635 cm-1 (s, v (Pb-O)), 783 cm-1 (m, v oop (C-H)ring), 860 cm-1 (s, v (C-C)), 1134 cm-1 (s, v (C-H)ring), 1210 cm-1 (vs, v (N-O) N-oxide), 1376 cm-1 (vs, v sym (CO2-Pb)), 1480 (m, v (CC)ring), 1543 and 1585 cm-1 (s, v asym (CO2-Pb)), 1655 cm-1 (m, v (CO)DMF), 3101 cm-1 (w, v sym (C-H)). elements.content: Potassium chromate (K2CrO4, 373.5 mg) was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to prepare a Cr­(VI) solution with the concentration of 1000 mg L–1. The other solutions were obtained by appropriate dilution of the stock solution. The amount of solid adsorbent was adjusted to be 10 mg in all experiments.
elements.clean_text:
Batch Adsorption Experiments

Potassium chromate (K2CrO4, 373.5 mg) was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to prepare a Cr(VI) solution with the concentration of 1000 mg L-1. The other solutions were obtained by appropriate dilution of the stock solution. The amount of solid adsorbent was adjusted to be 10 mg in all experiments.

elements.content: Evaluation of pH effects on Cr­(VI) adsorption was done at a pH range of 2.0–9.0. The adjustment of pH was performed by adding either 0.1 M HCl or 0.1 M NaOH while the initial concentration of Cr­(VI) was kept at 30 mg L–1 for all samples. The Cr­(VI) adsorption efficiency (% adsorption) was obtained using , % adsorption = ( C 0 − C e C 0 ) × 100 where C 0 and C e are the initial and the equilibrium Cr­(VI) concentrations (mg L–1), respectively.

elements.content: Ten samples were prepared by adding a fixed concentration of Cr­(VI) (30 mg L–1) to Falcon 50 mL conical tubes containing 10 mg of TMU-30 at 298 K. The adsorption process was stopped at different times from 1 to 120 min. Then, the mixture was centrifuged at 12000 rpm for 5 min and sampled for ICP analysis. The amount of Cr­(VI) adsorbed was calculated using , q t = ( C 0 − C t m ) V where q t and C t are the amount of Cr­(VI) adsorbed per unit mass of adsorbent (mg g–1) and the Cr­(VI) concentration (mg L–1) at time t (min), respectively; m is the adsorbent mass (g), and V is the volume (L) of the sample.

Kinetics for the Cr(VI) Adsorption

Ten samples were prepared by adding a fixed concentration of Cr(VI) (30 mg L-1) to Falcon 50 mL conical tubes containing 10 mg of TMU-30 at 298 K. The adsorption process was stopped at different times from 1 to 120 min. Then, the mixture was centrifuged at 12000 rpm for 5 min and sampled for ICP analysis. The amount of Cr(VI) adsorbed was calculated using , 2      q   t   =  (     C   0   -   C   t     m   )  V   where q t and C t are the amount of Cr(VI) adsorbed per unit mass of adsorbent (mg g-1) and the Cr(VI) concentration (mg L-1) at time t (min), respectively; m is the adsorbent mass (g), and V is the volume (L) of the sample.

elements.content: To study the adsorption isotherm, 50 mL of Cr­(VI) aqueous solution (the initial Cr­(VI) concentrations varying from 5 to 100 mg L–1) was poured into a Falcon conical tube with 10.0 mg of TMU-30 and shaken for 2 h at 298 K. The mixture was then centrifuged at 12000 rpm for 5 min, and the concentration of remaining Cr­(VI) was determined by ICP analysis. The equilibrium adsorption capacity was determined using , q e = ( C 0 − C e m ) V where q e is the equilibrium amount of Cr­(VI) adsorbed per unit mass of adsorbent (mg g–1) and C 0 and C e are initial and equilibrium concentrations of Cr­(IV), respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Isotherms and Thermodynamic Evaluations

To study the adsorption isotherm, 50 mL of Cr(VI) aqueous solution (the initial Cr(VI) concentrations varying from 5 to 100 mg L-1) was poured into a Falcon conical tube with 10.0 mg of TMU-30 and shaken for 2 h at 298 K. The mixture was then centrifuged at 12000 rpm for 5 min, and the concentration of remaining Cr(VI) was determined by ICP analysis. The equilibrium adsorption capacity was determined using , 3      q   e   =  (     C   0   -   C   e     m   )  V   where q e is the equilibrium amount of Cr(VI) adsorbed per unit mass of adsorbent (mg g-1) and C 0 and C e are initial and equilibrium concentrations of Cr(IV), respectively.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that TMU-30 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (Table S1 in the SI). Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2 (SI). The experimental PXRD of the synthesized TMU-30 is exactly comparable in pattern to the simulated one (Figure S2 in the SI).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Characterization of TMU-30

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that TMU-30 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (Table S1 in the SI). Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2 (SI). The experimental PXRD of the synthesized TMU-30 is exactly comparable in pattern to the simulated one (Figure S2 in the SI).

elements.content: Each lead­(II) center is surrounded by seven INO ligands in two different coordination modes forming a nine-coordinated sphere around lead­(II): five oxygen atoms from carboxylate groups and four oxygen atoms from N-oxide groups (Figure S3a in the SI). Carboxyl and N-oxide groups bind in modes chelating (μ2), chelating–bridging (μ–η2:η1), and μ2–O, respectively (Figure S3b in the SI). This pattern is repeated infinitely to form 1D Pb–O chains along the b-axis and face-shared PbO9 polyhedra (a). The Pb–O distances are 2.452–2.981 and 2.637–2.854 Å for oxygen atoms of carboxylate and N-oxide groups, respectively. The PbO9 nodes are linked by C(carboxylate) and N(N‑oxide) atoms, which connect each node to four neighboring rods in the a and c directions, generating 7.1 × 6.8 Å2 1D rhombic channels in the b axis (b). DMF molecules are located in the 1D channels comprising 20.4% of the crystal volume (2993.0 Å3 per unit cell) calculated by PLATON (c). The framework can be simplified by using 3-connected nets instead of metal centers and INO ligands. The most common 3-connected nets are the (10,3) nets [Well’s (10,3)]. Additionally, N and C(carboxylate) atoms around lead­(II) are arranged so that 3-connected nets with (10,3)-d topology are constructed (a). In TMU-30, connection of C1–N2 and C7–N1 from INO ligands gives rise to 4-fold cubic helices with opposite handedness (red and green linkages in a,b).

elements.content: The weight loss for TMU-30 according to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data was 6.12% at ∼465 K corresponding to 1 mol of DMF per mole of TMU-30. This framework was stable up to 592 K (Figure S4 in the SI). In order to evaluate the water stability of TMU-30, it was soaked in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns before and after the immersion indicated no differences in the patterns except changing two peaks of (002) and (402̅) located at 14.16° and 14.97° to a peak at 14.51° (Figure S5 in the SI). This alteration in the pattern can be attributed to decrease in lattice plane spacing due to exchange of DMF (kinetic diameter of 5.5 Å) with water (kinetic diameter of 2.6 Å). TGA (Figure S6 in the SI) and FT-IR (Figure S7 in the SI) analyses also confirmed this justification.
elements.clean_text:
Stability of TMU-30

The weight loss for TMU-30 according to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data was 6.12% at ~465 K corresponding to 1 mol of DMF per mole of TMU-30. This framework was stable up to 592 K (Figure S4 in the SI). In order to evaluate the water stability of TMU-30, it was soaked in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns before and after the immersion indicated no differences in the patterns except changing two peaks of (002) and (402̅) located at 14.16° and 14.97° to a peak at 14.51° (Figure S5 in the SI). This alteration in the pattern can be attributed to decrease in lattice plane spacing due to exchange of DMF (kinetic diameter of 5.5 Å) with water (kinetic diameter of 2.6 Å). TGA (Figure S6 in the SI) and FT-IR (Figure S7 in the SI) analyses also confirmed this justification.

elements.content:
Since Cr­(VI) ions exist in the form of oxo-anions in aqueous solutions, TMU-30 containing N-oxide groups with the potential positive charge was applied for Cr­(VI) oxo-anion adsorption.

Effect of pH

The role of pH in an adsorption process is to influence charge density on the adsorbent surface and to determine existing species of adsorbate in solution. The distribution of Cr­(VI) species is dependent on both pH and total Cr­(VI) concentration as shown in Figure S8 (SI). Since total concentration of Cr­(VI) species was changed between 5 and 100 mg L–1 in all specimens here, HCrO4 – and CrO4 2– are the most predominant species at the experimental pH range (2–9). Evaluation of pH effect on Cr­(VI) adsorption by TMU-30 revealed that the process is almost independent of the pH parameter. Unlike most typical adsorbents in which the maximum adsorption is reached at a particular pH toward special species, TMU-30 adsorbed all existing forms of Cr­(VI) over a wide range of pH values (2–9) (A). Also, the crystalline structure of TMU-30 did not change after the adsorptions were accomplished at various pH values up to 9 according to PXRD patterns (B). The crystalline pattern of TMU-30 began to change over pH of 9 (B,e). Therefore, subsequent tests were performed without any pH adjustment (pH = 5.6).
elements.clean_text:
Cr(VI) Adsorption Studies

Since Cr(VI) ions exist in the form of oxo-anions in aqueous solutions, TMU-30 containing N-oxide groups with the potential positive charge was applied for Cr(VI) oxo-anion adsorption.

Effect of pH

The role of pH in an adsorption process is to influence charge density on the adsorbent surface and to determine existing species of adsorbate in solution. The distribution of Cr(VI) species is dependent on both pH and total Cr(VI) concentration as shown in Figure S8 (SI). Since total concentration of Cr(VI) species was changed between 5 and 100 mg L-1 in all specimens here, HCrO4 - and CrO4 2- are the most predominant species at the experimental pH range (2-9). Evaluation of pH effect on Cr(VI) adsorption by TMU-30 revealed that the process is almost independent of the pH parameter. Unlike most typical adsorbents in which the maximum adsorption is reached at a particular pH toward special species, TMU-30 adsorbed all existing forms of Cr(VI) over a wide range of pH values (2-9) (A). Also, the crystalline structure of TMU-30 did not change after the adsorptions were accomplished at various pH values up to 9 according to PXRD patterns (B). The crystalline pattern of TMU-30 began to change over pH of 9 (B,e). Therefore, subsequent tests were performed without any pH adjustment (pH = 5.6).

elements.content: Determination of kinetic parameters is of great importance because they can be used to define the adsorption process and efficiency. Fast kinetics is very important, acceptable, and useful in aqueous phase adsorption. The adsorption capacity of Cr­(VI) onto TMU-30 increased with an increase in contact time and about 90% of final adsorption capacity was obtained in 5 min. After less than 10 min, 95% of Cr­(VI) can be adsorbed from the aqueous solution, and the solution became colorless (a,b). This time for Cr­(VI) adsorption is much faster than traditional adsorbents such as activated carbon and biomass, which need several hours to reach better removal percentage. In order to define the adsorption rate, a pseudo-second-order model with the highest value of correlation coefficient (R 2 = 0.999) was used to fit the kinetic results. The model can be expressed as , t q t = 1 k ad q e 2 + t q e where q t (mg g–1) is the adsorption capacity of TMU-30 at time t (min), q e (mg g–1) is the adsorption capacity at equilibrium, k ad (g mg–1 min–1) is the rate constant of adsorption. The values of q e and k ad were calculated from the slope and intercept of t/q t vs t plot (Figure S9a in the SI). The obtained rate constant, k ad, was 0.193 g mg–1 min–1 at 298 K, which is the highest one for the Cr­(VI) adsorption so far.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Kinetics

Determination of kinetic parameters is of great importance because they can be used to define the adsorption process and efficiency. Fast kinetics is very important, acceptable, and useful in aqueous phase adsorption. The adsorption capacity of Cr(VI) onto TMU-30 increased with an increase in contact time and about 90% of final adsorption capacity was obtained in 5 min. After less than 10 min, 95% of Cr(VI) can be adsorbed from the aqueous solution, and the solution became colorless (a,b). This time for Cr(VI) adsorption is much faster than traditional adsorbents such as activated carbon and biomass, which need several hours to reach better removal percentage. In order to define the adsorption rate, a pseudo-second-order model with the highest value of correlation coefficient (R 2 = 0.999) was used to fit the kinetic results. The model can be expressed as , 4      t     q   t     =   1     k   ad      q   e    2     +   t     q   e       where q t (mg g-1) is the adsorption capacity of TMU-30 at time t (min), q e (mg g-1) is the adsorption capacity at equilibrium, k ad (g mg-1 min-1) is the rate constant of adsorption. The values of q e and k ad were calculated from the slope and intercept of t/q t vs t plot (Figure S9a in the SI). The obtained rate constant, k ad, was 0.193 g mg-1 min-1 at 298 K, which is the highest one for the Cr(VI) adsorption so far.

Adsorption Isotherm

The effect of initial Cr(VI) concentration on adsorption was evaluated to determine the correlation between the adsorbent and the adsorbate as well as maximum adsorption capacity of the adsorbent. The adsorption on TMU-30 increased rapidly with increase in initial Cr(VI) concentration until the plot reached a plateau indicating saturation of the adsorbent sites (c).

elements.content: In order to derive an appropriate correlation between the experimental and theoretical data, the Langmuir model was applied (R 2 = 0.999), which is represented by , C e q e = C e q m + 1 k L q m where q m (mg g–1) and k L (L mg–1) are the maximum adsorption capacity of the adsorbent and Langmuir constant, respectively. The values of q m and k L were calculated from the slope and intercept of the C e/q e vs C e plot (Figure S9b in the SI). The Langmuir isotherm is applicable to monolayer adsorption with all identical and energetically equivalent adsorption sites. The q m was obtained 2.86 molCr(VI) molTMU‑30 –1 (145 mg g–1), which can be assumed one of the highest adsorbed amount on porous materials reported so far. Maximum adsorption capacity and time of equilibrium have been compared with other reported MOFs in .

Thermodynamic parameters were investigated at 288–323 K. The adsorption equilibrium constant (K 0), the changes in free energy (ΔG°, kJ mol–1), enthalpy (ΔH°, kJ mol–1), and entropy (ΔS°, kJ mol–1 K–1) were calculated based on – K 0 = q e C e Δ G ° = − R T ln ⁡ K 0 ln ⁡ K 0 = Δ S ° R − Δ H ° R T where R and T are the universal gas constant (8.314 J mol–1 K–1) and absolute temperature (K), respectively. Calculation of ΔS° and ΔH° values was carried out by drawing a linear plot of ln K 0 vs 1/T. (Figure S10 in the SI). presents the values of ΔG°, ΔS°, and ΔH° for the adsorption process. Positive values of ΔH° and ΔS° indicate that the process is endothermic and the adsorption is accompanied by an increase in disorder at the solid–liquid interface. Moreover, increase in temperature leads to a decrease in ΔG° value; therefore, it can be suggested that the adsorption process is spontaneous.

By comparison, TMU-30 has a superior performance for Cr­(VI) removal with very fast adsorption and highly efficient capacity. Moreover, the selective adsorption test of TMU-30 was carried out for variety of ions. Adsorption of cations and oxo-anions such as Na+, K+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Cr3+, MoO4 2–, and WO4 2– was investigated by TMU-30. The ICP spectrometry showed that TMU-30 adsorbed only MoO4 2– and WO4 2– (Figure S11 in the SI). However, TMU-30 could not selectively adsorb a certain species among CrO4 2–, MoO4 2–, and WO4 2–. These results confirmed selective adsorption of oxo-anion pollutants by TMU-30 from aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Selectivity Test of TMU-30

By comparison, TMU-30 has a superior performance for Cr(VI) removal with very fast adsorption and highly efficient capacity. Moreover, the selective adsorption test of TMU-30 was carried out for variety of ions. Adsorption of cations and oxo-anions such as Na+, K+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Cr3+, MoO4 2-, and WO4 2- was investigated by TMU-30. The ICP spectrometry showed that TMU-30 adsorbed only MoO4 2- and WO4 2- (Figure S11 in the SI). However, TMU-30 could not selectively adsorb a certain species among CrO4 2-, MoO4 2-, and WO4 2-. These results confirmed selective adsorption of oxo-anion pollutants by TMU-30 from aqueous solutions.

elements.content: The presence of Cr­(VI) species was confirmed by FT-IR and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDS) spectroscopies. FT-IR spectrum of TMU-30 showed a band at 1655 cm–1 corresponding to a DMF molecule before adsorption (Figure S12a in the SI). Moreover, there is a new band at 894 cm–1 after Cr­(VI) adsorption, which can be attributed to the stretching Cr–O vibration (Figure S12b). Also, EDS spectra of TMU-30 confirmed the presence of C, O, N, Pb, and Cr in the Cr­(VI) adsorbed sample (Figure S13 in the SI). TMU-30 particles were remarkably decreased in size to yield a rod-like morphology after Cr­(VI) adsorption (Figure S14 in the SI). To reveal the Cr­(VI) adsorption mechanism by TMU-30, XPS analysis was applied to determine the surface elements before and after adsorption. A new peak assigned to Cr 2p was clearly observed after Cr­(VI) adsorption on TMU-30 (a). The high-resolution XPS spectrum showed two new peaks located at 579.3 and 588.5 eV, without any splitting, which are characteristic for Cr 2p3/2–O and Cr 2p1/2–O, respectively (b). These results suggested that the oxidation state of Cr­(VI) after adsorption remained unchanged. The adsorption sites on TMU-30 were determined by high-resolution XPS spectra of N 1s and O 1s before and after adsorption. Before adsorption, three peaks were observed at 402.17, 399.49, and 398.28 in N 1s spectrum, which were characteristic of N–OINO (N–O(1)), N–C(INO), and N–C(DMF) in TMU-30 structure (c). After adsorption, the characteristic peak of N–O was deconvoluted into two peaks located at 402.41 and 401.5 eV. The peak at 402.41 represents N–OINO bonding in TMU-30 (N–O(1)), while the peak at 401.5 eV can be attributed to a new interaction between nitrogen atoms from INO and oxygen atoms from chromate (N–O(2)) (d). The broad peak of O 1s before adsorption can be fitted by four peaks at binding energies of 532.1(C–O), 531.3(C–O), 529.8(O–N), and 528.7(Pb–O) eV (e). After adsorption, O–N(2) information (interaction between oxygen atoms from chromate and nitrogen atoms from INO) appeared at 530.07 eV. The Pb–O peak at 528.84 eV showed an increase in intensity after chromium adsorption (f). This observation suggests that Cr–O interaction has been created because there is no difference between binding energies of Pb–O and Cr–O in XPS spectrum and both of them appear at the same binding energy. Therefore, the XPS results confirmed the formation of a new electrostatic interaction between the nitrogen of N-oxide groups from INO and oxygen atoms from chromate during the adsorption process.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Mechanism

The presence of Cr(VI) species was confirmed by FT-IR and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDS) spectroscopies. FT-IR spectrum of TMU-30 showed a band at 1655 cm-1 corresponding to a DMF molecule before adsorption (Figure S12a in the SI). Moreover, there is a new band at 894 cm-1 after Cr(VI) adsorption, which can be attributed to the stretching Cr-O vibration (Figure S12b). Also, EDS spectra of TMU-30 confirmed the presence of C, O, N, Pb, and Cr in the Cr(VI) adsorbed sample (Figure S13 in the SI). TMU-30 particles were remarkably decreased in size to yield a rod-like morphology after Cr(VI) adsorption (Figure S14 in the SI). To reveal the Cr(VI) adsorption mechanism by TMU-30, XPS analysis was applied to determine the surface elements before and after adsorption. A new peak assigned to Cr 2p was clearly observed after Cr(VI) adsorption on TMU-30 (a). The high-resolution XPS spectrum showed two new peaks located at 579.3 and 588.5 eV, without any splitting, which are characteristic for Cr 2p3/2-O and Cr 2p1/2-O, respectively (b). These results suggested that the oxidation state of Cr(VI) after adsorption remained unchanged. The adsorption sites on TMU-30 were determined by high-resolution XPS spectra of N 1s and O 1s before and after adsorption. Before adsorption, three peaks were observed at 402.17, 399.49, and 398.28 in N 1s spectrum, which were characteristic of N-OINO (N-O(1)), N-C(INO), and N-C(DMF) in TMU-30 structure (c). After adsorption, the characteristic peak of N-O was deconvoluted into two peaks located at 402.41 and 401.5 eV. The peak at 402.41 represents N-OINO bonding in TMU-30 (N-O(1)), while the peak at 401.5 eV can be attributed to a new interaction between nitrogen atoms from INO and oxygen atoms from chromate (N-O(2)) (d). The broad peak of O 1s before adsorption can be fitted by four peaks at binding energies of 532.1(C-O), 531.3(C-O), 529.8(O-N), and 528.7(Pb-O) eV (e). After adsorption, O-N(2) information (interaction between oxygen atoms from chromate and nitrogen atoms from INO) appeared at 530.07 eV. The Pb-O peak at 528.84 eV showed an increase in intensity after chromium adsorption (f). This observation suggests that Cr-O interaction has been created because there is no difference between binding energies of Pb-O and Cr-O in XPS spectrum and both of them appear at the same binding energy. Therefore, the XPS results confirmed the formation of a new electrostatic interaction between the nitrogen of N-oxide groups from INO and oxygen atoms from chromate during the adsorption process.

elements.content: A new MOF, [Pb­(INO)2]2·DMF (TMU-30), consisting of 1D rhombic channels (7.1 × 6.8 Å2) was successfully prepared. TMU-30 showed superior performance for Cr­(VI) adsorption with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol–1 or 145 mg g–1). The Cr­(VI) adsorption was effectively carried out on TMU-30 adsorbent over a pH range of 2.0–9.0. Moreover, TMU-30 could selectively adsorb heavy metal oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous solution. Nitrogen sites of N-oxide functional groups with potential positive charge are responsible for the adsorption of Cr­(VI). These results indicate that MOFs based on pyridine carboxylate N-oxide derivatives can be promising candidates for capture and removal of oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous environments. TMU-30 is a basic model of the MOFs, which can be improved in terms of adsorption properties and environmental impacts by replacement of its central metal.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A new MOF, [Pb(INO)2]2⋅DMF (TMU-30), consisting of 1D rhombic channels (7.1 × 6.8 Å2) was successfully prepared. TMU-30 showed superior performance for Cr(VI) adsorption with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol-1 or 145 mg g-1). The Cr(VI) adsorption was effectively carried out on TMU-30 adsorbent over a pH range of 2.0-9.0. Moreover, TMU-30 could selectively adsorb heavy metal oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous solution. Nitrogen sites of N-oxide functional groups with potential positive charge are responsible for the adsorption of Cr(VI). These results indicate that MOFs based on pyridine carboxylate N-oxide derivatives can be promising candidates for capture and removal of oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous environments. TMU-30 is a basic model of the MOFs, which can be improved in terms of adsorption properties and environmental impacts by replacement of its central metal.

cln_elements.content:
A new metal−organic framework (MOF) containing N-oxide groups has been used for highly efficient adsorption of Cr­(VI) from aqueous solutions with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol−1 or 145 mg g−1).

Stability of TMU-30

The weight loss for TMU-30 according to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data was 6.12% at ∼465 K corresponding to 1 mol of DMF per mole of TMU-30. This framework was stable up to 592 K (Figure S4 in the SI). In order to evaluate the water stability of TMU-30, it was soaked in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns before and after the immersion indicated no differences in the patterns except changing two peaks of (002) and (402̅) located at 14.16° and 14.97° to a peak at 14.51° (Figure S5 in the SI). This alteration in the pattern can be attributed to decrease in lattice plane spacing due to exchange of DMF (kinetic diameter of 5.5 Å) with water (kinetic diameter of 2.6 Å). TGA (Figure S6 in the SI) and FT-IR (Figure S7 in the SI) analyses also confirmed this justification.

Conclusion

A new MOF, [Pb­(INO)2]2·DMF (TMU-30), consisting of 1D rhombic channels (7.1 × 6.8 Å2) was successfully prepared. TMU-30 showed superior performance for Cr­(VI) adsorption with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol–1 or 145 mg g–1). The Cr­(VI) adsorption was effectively carried out on TMU-30 adsorbent over a pH range of 2.0–9.0. Moreover, TMU-30 could selectively adsorb heavy metal oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous solution. Nitrogen sites of N-oxide functional groups with potential positive charge are responsible for the adsorption of Cr­(VI). These results indicate that MOFs based on pyridine carboxylate N-oxide derivatives can be promising candidates for capture and removal of oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous environments. TMU-30 is a basic model of the MOFs, which can be improved in terms of adsorption properties and environmental impacts by replacement of its central metal.
cln_elements.clean_text:
A new metal-organic framework (MOF) containing N-oxide groups has been used for highly efficient adsorption of Cr(VI) from aqueous solutions with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol-1 or 145 mg g-1).

Stability of TMU-30

The weight loss for TMU-30 according to thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data was 6.12% at ~465 K corresponding to 1 mol of DMF per mole of TMU-30. This framework was stable up to 592 K (Figure S4 in the SI). In order to evaluate the water stability of TMU-30, it was soaked in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns before and after the immersion indicated no differences in the patterns except changing two peaks of (002) and (402̅) located at 14.16° and 14.97° to a peak at 14.51° (Figure S5 in the SI). This alteration in the pattern can be attributed to decrease in lattice plane spacing due to exchange of DMF (kinetic diameter of 5.5 Å) with water (kinetic diameter of 2.6 Å). TGA (Figure S6 in the SI) and FT-IR (Figure S7 in the SI) analyses also confirmed this justification. 

Conclusion

A new MOF, [Pb(INO)2]2⋅DMF (TMU-30), consisting of 1D rhombic channels (7.1 × 6.8 Å2) was successfully prepared. TMU-30 showed superior performance for Cr(VI) adsorption with very fast kinetics (<10 min) and high capacity (2.86 mol mol-1 or 145 mg g-1). The Cr(VI) adsorption was effectively carried out on TMU-30 adsorbent over a pH range of 2.0-9.0. Moreover, TMU-30 could selectively adsorb heavy metal oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous solution. Nitrogen sites of N-oxide functional groups with potential positive charge are responsible for the adsorption of Cr(VI). These results indicate that MOFs based on pyridine carboxylate N-oxide derivatives can be promising candidates for capture and removal of oxo-anion pollutants from aqueous environments. TMU-30 is a basic model of the MOFs, which can be improved in terms of adsorption properties and environmental impacts by replacement of its central metal.
